qas.question: When is distortion most common on a gramophone record?

answers.text: Distortion towards the end of the side

qas.question: What happens as a record wears?
What is a drawback of using gramophones?

answers.text: fidelity steadily declines as playback progresses

qas.question: How much vinyl can be found at the start of an LP?
Where can you find only 200-210mm of vinyl?

context: A further limitation of the gramophone record is that <a2_0>fidelity steadily declines as playback progresses<a2_0/>; there is more vinyl per second available for fine reproduction of high frequencies at the large-diameter beginning of the groove than exist at the smaller-diameters close to the end of the side. At the start of a groove on an LP there are <a3_0>510 mm<a3_0/> of vinyl per second traveling past the stylus while the <a4_0>ending of the groove<a4_0/> gives 200–210 mm of vinyl per second — less than half the linear resolution. <a0_0><a1_0>Distortion<a1_0/> towards the end of the side<a0_0/> is likely to become more apparent as record wear increases.*
